meta.name: Granule cell 2019 - Regular firing
meta.description:
Granule Cell 2019 - Regular firing model. Typical regular response to a steady current injection

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 32°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -70
3) Currents injection used in the paper = 10, 16 and 22pA
4) Currents injection, 100ms delay, 2000ms injection and 2000ms tstop (length of the simulation)

meta.name: Granule cell 2009 modeling Na+ channels to ensure fast spiking and back-propagation (GrC2009Diwakar)

author.given_name: Shyam Diwakar, Jacopo Magistretti, Mitchell Goldfarb, Giovanni Naldi, Egidio

meta.description: Diwakar et al. 2009 model of GranuleCell (GrC) and published in 10.1152/jn.90382.2008 This is the multi-compartment model. It models the rat granule cells because the model was derived from slices taken from 20 +/- 2 days old rats. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 116835. Code to Model template for GrC2009Diwakar This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "GrC2009Diwakar" ) Model description in ModelDB #116835 A detailed multicompartmental model was used to study neuronal electroresponsiveness of cerebellar granule cells in rats. Here we show that, in cerebellar granule cells, Na+ channels are enriched in the axon, especially in the hillock, but almost absent from soma and dendrites. Numerical simulations indicated that granule cells have a compact electrotonic structure allowing EPSPs to diffuse with little attenuation from dendrites to axon. The spike arose almost simultaneously along the whole axonal ascending branch and invaded the hillock, whose activation promoted spike back-propagation with marginal delay (<200 micros) and attenuation (<20 mV) into the somato-dendritic compartment. For details check the cited article.

meta.name: Granule cell - Mono compartmental
meta.description:
Cerebellar Granule cell single compartmental model.

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 30°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -80
3) Current injections physiological range = 0nA to 0.03nA (30pA)

meta.name: Granule cell 2019 - Mild adapting
meta.description:
Granule Cell 2019 - Mild adapting model. After the first 600-700ms the action potential generation will be reduced to a sparse activity.

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 32°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -70
3) Currents injection used in the paper = 10, 16 and 22pA
4) Currents injection, 100ms delay, 2000ms injection and 2000ms tstop (length of the simulation)

meta.name: Granule cell 2019 - Strong adapting
meta.description:
Granule cell 2019 - Strong adapting model. After the first few hundred ms the cell will stop firing with long pauses between sparse action potentials.

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 32°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -70
3) Currents injection used in the paper = 10, 16 and 22pA
4) Currents injection, 100ms delay, 2000ms injection and 2000ms tstop (length of the simulation)

meta.name: Granule cell - Multi compartmental
meta.description:
Cerebellar Granule cell multi compartmental model.

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 30°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -70
3) Current injections physiological range = 0nA to 0.03nA (30pA)

meta.name: Granule cell 2019 - Accelerating
meta.description:
Granule Cell 2019 - Accelerating model. The model will show an incresing in action potential generation after 1600ms of simulations.

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 32°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -70
3) Currents injection used in the paper = 10, 16 and 22pA
4) Currents injection, 100ms delay, 2000ms injection and 2000ms tstop (length of the simulation)
